filename: FL6_SA FL Structural modifications of footpad and nerves supply.pdf
text:
Forelimb anatomy; Small animal
Structural modifications of 
footpad and nerves supply
Skin 
Footpads and Claws
Lymphatic drainage
Forelimb nerve supply  
Learning Outcomes  
1. Explain anatomical MODIFICATIONS to integumentary 
system at the extremities of the digits in relation to 
normal function.
2. Identify anatomical features of FOOTPAD and CLAW.
3. Demonstrate the components of lymphatic system, 
flow of lymph within the forelimb and locate major 
LYMPH NODES.
4. Explain major NERVES SUPPLY to forelimb.
3
Footpads
GDD_p, Lo# 
Carpal / stopper pad:
– protects accessory carpal bone
• Metacarpal pad x 1: (heart shaped)
– overlies MCP joints
• Digital pads x 4:
– overlie DIP joints
Functions:
• Resistance to trauma / wear & tear
• Traction – prevent slipping
• Anti-concussive
• Protect deep structures
• Support digit
– Allow weight bearing over DP, 
MP, PP and MCP joints
A
B
C
D
E
A. Carpal pad; B. dewclaw
C. Metacarpal pad; D. Digital pad
E. Claw
Organisation of Skin- brief overview 
GDD_p, Lo# 
Skin= Epidermis and 
Dermis 
Epidermis:
• Cells constantly produced by 
germinative layer
• Cells age as move outwards
• Dead at surface & slough
• Constant replacement
• No blood supply
• No nerve supply
– Insensitive and no bleeding
Dermis:
• Blood supply
• Nerve supply
– Sensitive and bleeds
• Supports germinative layer
- active production of skin cells

EPIDERMIS
Papillary region
Reticular region
Dermis (corium)
Hypodermis (Subcutaneous layer)
(not a component of skin)
Layer of loose connective tissue
Vascular connective 
tissue layer 
Consists of Stratified 
squamous keratinised 
4
5
Footpad modifications 
GDD_p, Lo# 
Modifications to epidermis 
according to function
Trauma resistance:
• Increased skin thickness
• Increased turnover of cells
– Active germinative layer
• Deposition of keratin
– Hard proteinaceous material
– keratinised stratified squamous 
epithelium
• Rough surface (conical papillae)
– grip
• Sweat glands
– heat loss
• Variable amounts pigmentation
• Hairless, thick skin
Histology of Footpad: Covered in detail in S2
6
Footpad – Components 
GDD_p, Lo# 
• Skin
– Epidermis
– Germinative layer
– Dermis
• Superficial fascia
• Digital cushion
– Rich in fibro-elastic tissue
– Fat
– Vascular supply 
Function = Shock absorption
Clinical considerations 
• Wounds
– Elastic tissue
– Contains excessive vascular channels
• Sweat
– bandaging
• Damage to DDFT
– ‘Stubbed toe’
7
Claw 
• No superficial fascia
• Dermis
– fused directly to periosteum of 
ungual process of DP
• Germinative layer
– Active in 2 areas only
• Epidermis
– heavily keratinised = horn
• Stratum tectorum
– waterproof surface layer
– Produced by skin in ungual recesses
Germinative area 1:
• Recess between claw and skin
• Horn grows over dorsal and lateral 
surfaces of ungual process
• Horse-shoe shaped in transverse 
section / short axis
Germinative area 2:
• Palmar surface of ungual process
• Horn covers palmar surfaceP3 Bone 
8
Claw 
GDD_p, Lo# 
•Normal claw - tip touches ground
Position maintained by:
• Extensor tendons
• Dorsal elastic ligament
• Balanced by DDFT
• Continuous growth
• Tip wears naturally
• Reduced wear
– Not walking
– Walking on soft ground
– Dew claw
– DDFT damage (‘Stubbed toe’)
• Claw grows in circular fashion
– Can eventually grow into pad
ET
DEL 
DDF
9
Clinical considerations 
GDD_p, Lo# 
• Horn = epidermis
– Insensitive so can cut
• Dermis
– contains blood & nerve supply
– Don’t cut too far!
• Non-pigmented claws
– easier to clip
Cut line 
10
Cat
GDD_p, Lo# 
• Same number of pads & claws
• Same components and functions
• May be pigmented
• Pressure on pad – unsheath claw
• Claws remain sharp for huntgin / 
climbing etc
11
Lymphatic system- Recap 
GDD_p, Lo# 
Cardiovascular system:
• Continuous system
• Leaky capillary bed
• Exchange of material e.g. fluid, protein
• Net loss
• Fluid accumulation
– oedema & swelling in peripheral 
tissues
Lymphatic vessels 
• Recovery / scavenging system
• Series of individual vessels
• Thin walled
• Run from periphery to thoracic duct
• Thoracic duct empties into caudal 
vena cava
• Transports lost material back into 
systemic circulation
Right 
Heart 
Left 
Heart 
Arterial circulation 
Venous circulation 
Lymphatic 
circulation 
Lung
Lymph 
node 
Lymph 
vessels 
12
Lymphatic system
GDD_p, Lo# 
Lymph nodes
• Filters
• Located where lymph vessels converge
• Prevent contaminants reaching systemic 
circulation
• Remove invading organisms e.g. bacteria
• Contain defence cells
Forelimb lymph nodes
• Prescapular L.n
• Axillary L.n
• Enlarged in response to infection
• Can use to differentiate between 
localised/ generalised disease
• Important in large animals for 
meat inspection
Pre-scapular L.N
Axillary L.N
13
Nervous system (Nerve supply)
GDD_p, Lo# 
Brachial plexus Supplies:
• Selected extrinsic muscles:
– Pectoral muscles
– Latissimus dorsi
– Serratus ventralis
• All Intrinsic muscles
– Subscapular nerve
– Suprascapular nerve
– Musculocutaneous nerve
– Axillary nerve
– Radial nerve
– Median & Ulnar nerve
© Guide to the Dissection of 
the Dog,  7th Ed. Page 123
14
Subscapular /suprascapular nerves
GDD_p, Lo# 
• Medial shoulder support
– Subscapularis muscle
• Lateral shoulder support
– Supraspinatous muscle
– Infraspinatous muscle
Motor nerves only (No cutaneous sensation)
Suprascapular nerve
Subscapular nerve
15
Musculocutaneous Nerve
GDD_p, Lo# 
Mixed nerve
Sensory:
• Cutaneous sensation to:
- Cranial & medial aspect of elbow
- Medial aspect of antebrachium
Motor:
• Elbow flexors
– Brachialis muscle
– Biceps brachii muscle
– Coracobrachialis muscle
If damaged
• No compensation
• Loss of elbow flexion
Musculocutaneous n. 
16
Axillary Nerve
GDD_p, Lo# 
Motor supply:
• Dedicated shoulder flexors
– Deltoideus muscle
– Teres major muscle
Sensory fibres:
• Cutaneous sensation to:
– Lateral aspect shoulder and 
brachium
Damage – compensation by
• Latissimus dorsi
• Long head triceps
Mixed nerve
Mesculocutaneous n.
Axillary n.  
17
Median & Ulnar Nerve
GDD_p, Lo# 
Mixed nerve
Sensory fibres
• Cutaneous sensation to:
– Caudal & palmar aspect limb
– Dorsal aspect 5th digit
Motor supply:
• Carpal & digital flexors
– Flexor carpi ulnaris muscle
– Flexor carpi radialis muscle
– Superficial digital flexor muscle
– Deep digital flexor muscle
• Damage – no compensation
– Loss of distal limb flexion
Musculocutaneous n.
Axillary n.
Median n. & Ulnar n.
18
Radial Nerve
GDD_p, Lo# 
Mixed nerve
Sensory fibres:
• Cutaneous sensation to:
– Dorsal & cranial aspect limb
– Except dorsal aspect 5th digit
Motor supply
• Extensors of elbow
– Triceps muscle
• Extensors of carpus & digits
– Extensor carpi radialis muscle
– Extensor carpi ulnaris /ulnaris
lateralis muscle
– Common digital extensor muscle
– Lateral digital extensor muscle
Musculocutaneous n.
Axillary n.
Median n. & Ulnar n.
Radial n.
19
Radial nerve – route 
GDD_p, Lo# 
• Starts medial
• Passes caudal to shoulder
• Passes through Triceps
– Supplies Triceps
• Follows musculospiral groove 
(& Brachialis muscle)
• Branch - lateral epicondyle
– Supplies distal limb extensors
• Branch - cranial / dorsal aspect limb
– Runs alongside cephalic vein
– Supplies cutaneous sensation
• Humeral fracture most common 
cause of damage
• Deficits depend on level of damage
Lateral aspect
20
Radial nerve damage 
GDD_p, Lo# 
Motor losses 
Proximal level:
• All extensor muscles affected
• Cannot extend elbow, carpus or digits
• Cannot weight bear
• Limb appears longer than opposite one
Distal level:
• Extensors of carpus & digits affected
– Cannot extend carpus / digits
• Triceps intact
– Can extend elbow
– Can weight bear if limb extended
– Can learn to swing leg to compensate
GDD_p, Lo# 
21
Radial nerve damage 
Sensory losses 
• Cranial & dorsal aspect limb
• Trauma to dorsal aspect paw if drags
• Self mutilation
• Check sensation using forceps
• Check pre-op humeral fracture repair so cannot be blamed!
Musculocutaneous n.
Axillary n.
Median n. & Ulnar n.
Radial n.
Proximal level:
• All extensor muscles affected
• Cannot extend elbow, carpus or digits
• Cannot weight bear
• Limb appears longer than opposite one
Distal level:
• Extensors of carpus & digits affected
– Cannot extend carpus / digits
• Triceps intact
– Can extend elbow
– Can weight bear if limb extended
– Can learn to swing leg to compensate
Motor losses 
22
Brachial plexus damage
GDD_p, Lo# 
Tear / avulsion = stretching
• High impact collision
• Head & neck one direction – limb the other
• Variable degrees of damage
• Regeneration possible with time
• Mismatching may result in
aberrant sensation
Tumour
• Effects depend on which nerves affected
Effect on limb:
• Can protract / abduct limb
• Cannot retract / adduct limb
• Cannot extend / flex limb
• Cannot weight bear
• No cutaneous sensation on limb or lateral 
thorax to level of 3rd intercostal space
